text: Chairman Boehner. The Committee on Education and the Workforce will come to order.
label: BODY

text: We're meeting today to hear testimony on “Back to Work: the Administration's Plan for
label: BODY

text: Economic Recovery and the Workforce Investment Act.”  Under Committee rule 12(b), opening
label: BODY

text: statements are limited to the Chairman or Ranking Minority Member of the Committee.  Therefore,
label: BODY

text: if other Members have statements, they will be included in the hearing record.
label: BODY

text: And with that, I ask unanimous consent for the hearing record to remain open for 14 days to
label: BODY

text: allow Members' statements and other extraneous material referenced during the hearing to be
label: BODY

text: submitted for the official record.  Without objection, so ordered.
label: BODY

text: OPENING STATEMENT OF CHAIRMAN JOHN BOEHNER, COMMITTEE
label: HH2

text: ON EDUCATION AND THE WORKFORCE
label: HH3

text: Let me start this morning by welcoming our distinguished guest today, the Secretary of
label: BODY

text: Labor, Elaine Chao, and I also would like to welcome my counterpart, the gentleman from
label: BODY

text: California, Mr. Miller, and the other Members of our Committee.
label: BODY

text: During his State of the Union address, President Bush laid out a comprehensive plan to
label: BODY

text: speed our economic recovery and promote long-term job growth and investment.  His plan also
label: BODY

text: provides specific assistance, in the form of personal re-employment accounts, to help unemployed
label: BODY

text: Americans who are struggling to return to work.
label: BODY

text: At a time when the economy is struggling but also improving, it is important that we focus
label: BODY

text: on giving the unemployed more flexibility and choices in their employment search.  And even
label: BODY

text: though the most recent Labor Department statistics reveal that unemployment is down to 5.7
label: BODY

text: percent this month, we still need to examine new ways to help working families across this country
label: BODY

text: during the time when they need it most.
label: BODY

text: On January 29th, Congressmen Jon Porter, Buck McKeon, Todd Tiahrt, and others
label: BODY

text: introduced the Back to Work Incentive Act, which reflects the President's plan to create these
label: BODY

text: accounts, and aid unemployed workers who need the most help in getting back to work.  I am
label: BODY

text: pleased to be a co-sponsor of this important measure.
label: BODY

text: The Back to Work Incentive Act represents a new and innovative approach to helping the
label: BODY

text: unemployed get back on their feet.  As President Bush has said, one worker out of work is one too
label: BODY

text: many, and his plan will help working families in times when they need it most.
label: BODY

text: Now, workers can use the Back to Work accounts for a variety of services to help them find
label: BODY

text: a good job, including job training, child care, transportation, housing assistance, and other expenses
label: BODY

text: in helping find a new job. Recipients will be able to keep the balance of their $3,000 back to work
label: BODY

text: account as a cash re-employment bonus if they become re-employed within 13 weeks, creating an
label: BODY

text: important incentive to return to work quickly. The more quickly a job is obtained, the larger the re-
label: BODY

text: employment bonus will be.
label: BODY

text: States such as Iowa, Pennsylvania, and Washington have experimented with personal re-
label: BODY

text: employment accounts, and the results have been very positive.
label: BODY

text: One of the exciting aspects of the new Back to Work accounts is that they empower
label: BODY

text: individual recipients to make choices appropriate for their own circumstances.  Recipients will be
label: BODY

text: able to create re-employment plans that help them navigate all the options available -- such as
label: BODY

text: career counseling or training for a new profession in which they can be employed. By providing
label: BODY

text: choice and flexibility, we can get people back into a steady, good-paying job as quickly as possible.
label: BODY

text: This new benefit supplements and enhances the services that are already available for those
label: BODY

text: who are most likely to face obstacles in finding and keeping new employment. These Back to
label: BODY

text: Work accounts will not only provide the unemployed with another important benefit in helping
label: BODY

text: them find a new job, but will be efficiently administered through the easily accessible One Stop
label: BODY

text: Career Center system, established through the Federal Workforce Investment Act (WIA).
label: BODY

text: The Workforce Investment Act (WIA) and the one-stop delivery system it created represent
label: BODY

text: the nation's primary investment in workforce development.  WIA assistance is vital to helping
label: BODY

text: workers find new or better jobs in this time of economic recovery.  Through the one-stop delivery
label: BODY

text: system, job seekers have access to labor market information, job counseling, and job training to
label: BODY

text: help them get back on their feet. In addition, they have access to numerous other federal programs
label: BODY

text: that provide services to job seekers.  These Back to Work accounts will be an important new
label: BODY

text: benefit that will be offered seamlessly and efficiently through the WIA delivery system.
label: BODY

text: The 21st Century Competitiveness Subcommittee, chaired by Congressman Buck McKeon,
label: BODY

text: will lead this Committee's efforts to reauthorize the Workforce Investment Act this year, and will
label: BODY

text: focus on improving the system to help achieve the original vision of the law when it was enacted in
label: BODY

text: 1998, which was to create a seamless workforce development system for workers and employers.
label: BODY

text: While we expect to move the Back to Work Incentive Act as a stand-alone bill, we also
label: BODY

text: expect to address the President's proposal as part of our efforts to reauthorize WIA. Particularly
label: BODY

text: during a sluggish economy, WIA programs can play a role in helping Americans get back to work,
label: BODY

text: or retain for new jobs.
label: BODY

text: I look forward to working with President Bush, Subcommittee Chairman McKeon,
label: BODY

text: Congressman Porter, Secretary Chao, and my friends on the Democrat side of the aisle to move this
label: BODY

text: proposal quickly and make this innovative plan a reality for working families who need the help the
label: BODY

text: most, and certainly they need it quickly.
label: BODY

text: I now yield to my friend and Ranking Member of the Committee, George Miller.
label: BODY

text: WRITTEN OPENING STATEMENT OF CHAIRMAN JOHN BOEHNER,
label: BODY

text: COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE WORKFORCE – SEE APPENDIX A
label: BODY

text: OPENING STATEMENT OF RANKING MEMBER GEORGE MILLER,
label: HH2

text: COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE WORKFORCE
label: HH3

text: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.  Madame Secretary, welcome back to the Committee.  We look
label: BODY

text: forward to hearing your comments today regarding the President's proposal for personal re-
label: BODY

text: employment accounts. The question we will have, obviously, is whether or not this proposal meets
label: BODY

text: the demands that are being placed on unemployed workers today in our current economy.
label: BODY

text: This proposal comes at a time when working families are facing a weak economy, wracked
label: BODY

text: by job insecurity, unemployment, corporate malfeasance, and battered retirement savings.  By
label: BODY

text: almost any measure you can think of, for wages, job security, retirement security, middle-class
label: BODY

text: Americans are worse off today than they were two years ago, or at any time in the past decade.
label: BODY

text: It's not a question of whether we have one unemployed worker in this country, which would
label: BODY

text: be too many for the President; we have 8 million unemployed workers in this country.  And
label: BODY

text: minority and women workers have been particularly hard hit. More than 1 million workers, 1
label: BODY

text: million individuals, many heads of households, have exhausted their federal unemployment
label: BODY

text: benefits and cannot find work. The number of workers unemployed for more than 15 weeks has
label: BODY

text: increased almost 140 percent in the two years since you took office.
label: BODY

text: The paycheck for America's most vulnerable workers, those making the minimum wage,
label: BODY

text: will soon be at its lowest value since the Eisenhower administration a half a century ago.  And yet
label: BODY

text: we have seen absolutely no leadership from the majority in this Congress or from the Bush
label: BODY

text: Administration to provide these men and women with a decent increase in their earnings.
label: BODY

text: For some reason, this Administration and the Republican Congress can see fit to give $2
label: BODY

text: trillion in tax breaks to the wealthiest Americans during this recession, and during a time of
label: BODY

text: impending war, but we can't give 75 cents an hour to the poorest workers in this nation this year.
label: BODY

text: The precipitous drop in the stock market over the past two years has cost employees over
label: BODY

text: $175 billion in 401(k) investments and assets.  Thousands of these employees who lost hundreds of
label: BODY

text: millions of dollars of irreplaceable life savings and retirement benefits due to corporate fraud and
label: BODY

text: abuse, are still awaiting help from the Department of Labor to recoup their losses more than a year
label: BODY

text: later.
label: BODY

text: Corporate pension plans' under-funding have reached a staggering level of $300 billion.
label: BODY

text: This requires that the Department of Labor immediately address the serious problem that threatens
label: BODY

text: the retirement security of tens of millions of Americans.  The public Pension Benefit Guaranty
label: BODY

text: Corporation, the agency that 44 million Americans rely on to pay their pensions if their companies
label: BODY

text: are bankrupt, has record deficits close to $10 billion when accounting for future liabilities, and
label: BODY

text: huge corporations are lining up to dump their pension burdens into this corporation every month as
label: BODY

text: part of their bankruptcy bail-out plans.  Most recently we see Bethlehem National, and the question
label: BODY

text: is how soon will the airlines off-load their employees' pensions into the Pension Benefit Guaranty
label: BODY

text: Corporation? This threat to the employees' pensions does not even take into consideration the threat
label: BODY

text: to their health insurance benefits that are also under attack.
label: BODY

text: Not only is the federal treasury facing $300 billion in red ink next year and $2 trillion over
label: BODY

text: the next decade as a result of the administration's irresponsible fiscal policies, but now state and
label: BODY

text: local governments are confronting $85 billion in deficits, forcing cuts in health care, child care,
label: BODY

text: education, and training, and tomorrow this Congress will add $11 billion to the burden of those
label: BODY

text: states with the passage of the Welfare Reform Bill.
label: BODY

text: The American public is starting to understand that this Administration and this Congress
label: BODY

text: have turned a deaf ear to the worsening economic security of millions of Americans worried about
label: BODY

text: their jobs, their families, and their retirement security.  There is no additional help for more than 1
label: BODY

text: million workers who have exhausted their federal unemployment benefits and can't find work.
label: BODY

text: There is no support for a modest increase in the minimum wage.  There is vigorous opposition to
label: BODY

text: the rights of working people to join unions, as demonstrated in the cases of the Department of
label: BODY

text: Homeland Security and the baggage handlers and others at our airports.
label: BODY

text: Failures by the Department of Labor over the last 15 months, since the beginning of the
label: BODY

text: investigation of Enron, to try and recover hundreds of millions of dollars in retirement investments
label: BODY

text: lost due to corporate fraud and abuse, the promotion of unsound and unfair pension changes, like
label: BODY

text: the cash balance conversions that could impoverish millions of middle-aged and older employees,
label: BODY

text: and the investment advice proposal that former SEC Chairman Arthur Levitt says violates the one
label: BODY

text: bedrock principle of investing.
label: BODY

text: Given this record, I am at a loss to see how the Bush Administration's proposal for re-
label: BODY

text: employment accounts speaks to the deep underlying problems facing working men and women in
label: BODY

text: this dreadful economy.  How will these accounts help the 1 million workers who have already
label: BODY

text: exhausted their federal extended benefits?  How will they help workers find jobs in communities
label: BODY

text: where no work is available?  And how will this Department respond to the report by the previous
label: BODY

text: Bush Administration that concluded that these accounts do very little for workers who are living in
label: BODY

text: areas of moderate or high unemployment, of which there are now millions of Americans that share
label: BODY

text: that burden.
label: BODY

text: I am eager to hear your testimony today, Madame Secretary, but I must say that I am very
label: BODY

text: concerned about this Administration's lack of attention to the welfare and the well-being of millions
label: BODY

text: of middle-class working families who still see their livelihoods and their retirements threatened by
label: BODY

text: this economy and by the inability of this Administration to respond to their needs.  Simply cutting
label: BODY

text: off people's benefits and not giving them additional work is not going to provide the kind of
label: BODY

text: economic recovery that this nation needs and this nation's families want so dearly.  Thank you very
label: BODY

text: much.
label: BODY

text: Chairman Boehner. Before I introduce the Secretary, let me take a moment to welcome the
label: BODY

text: newest member of our Committee, Phil Gingrey, of Georgia.
label: BODY

text: Dr. Gingrey was elected to our Committee last night. He is an OB/GYN, a former Marietta
label: BODY

text: school board member, and most recently served in the Georgia State Senate from 1998 until he was
label: BODY

text: elected to Congress this November. He will serve on the Subcommittee on Select Education and
label: BODY

text: the Subcommittee on 21st Century Competitiveness.  I want to welcome Dr. Gingrey to the
label: BODY

text: Committee.
label: BODY

text: It's now my pleasure to introduce the Secretary of Labor, Elaine Chao.  Secretary Chao is
label: BODY

text: the nation's 24th Secretary of Labor, and is a champion of the nation's contemporary workforce.
label: BODY

text: She has worked to focus the Labor Department on the modern realities of workers' lives.
label: BODY

text: Prior to assuming the position of Secretary, she was a director of the Peace Corps, and later
label: BODY

text: President and Chief Executive Officer of United Way of America.  Secretary Chao's previous
label: BODY

text: government experience includes Deputy Secretary at the U.S. Department of Transportation.
label: BODY

text: In addition, her business experience includes positions at Bank of America, Capital Markets
label: BODY

text: Group, and Citicorp.  And prior to her nomination as Secretary, she was a distinguished Fellow at
label: BODY

text: the Heritage Foundation. Secretary Chao received her MBA from the Harvard Business School and
label: BODY

text: her undergraduate degree in economics from Mount Holyoke College.
label: BODY

text: Before the Secretary begins her testimony, I want to remind all the Members that we will
label: BODY

text: impose a five-minute limit on questions.  The Secretary is only with us for a short time today, and
label: BODY

text: she must excuse herself at noon. So I would ask Members to be mindful of the clock.
label: BODY

text: And with that, Madame Secretary, welcome and you may begin.
label: BODY

text: STATEMENT OF ELAINE L. CHAO, SECRETARY OF LABOR, U.S.
label: HH3

text: DEPARTMENT OF LABOR, WASHINGTON, D.C.
label: HH3

text: Good morning, Mr. Chairman, Congressman Miller, and Members of the Committee.
label: BODY

text: Thank you for the opportunity to testify on the provisions of the President's economic growth and
label: BODY

text: jobs package that will help workers with immediate benefits and long-term opportunities.
label: BODY

text: I want to commend you and the Members of this Committee for your leadership in
label: BODY

text: introducing the Back to Work Incentive Act, H.R. 444, which would establish personal re-
label: BODY

text: employment accounts for an estimated 1.2 million workers.
label: BODY

text: I would also like to describe some of the innovative changes we proposed to the workforce
label: BODY

text: investment system through reauthorization of the Workforce Investment Act of 1998.  I will
label: BODY

text: summarize my statement, Mr. Chairman, but ask that my prepared statement be included for the
label: BODY

text: record.
label: BODY

text: Last month, President Bush announced a comprehensive growth and jobs package to
label: BODY

text: stimulate spending, promote investment, create jobs, and deliver critical help to unemployed
label: BODY

text: workers.  If enacted, his plan will help create 1.4 million jobs by the end of 2004.
label: BODY

text: I think we all agree that current unemployment rates, while low by historical standards, are
label: BODY

text: still too high. Our goal is to preserve the hard-won gains the economy has made, to speed up
label: BODY

text: growth and create more jobs in both the short term and the long term.
label: BODY

text: One of the unique features of the President's economic recovery plan is its new approach to
label: BODY

text: addressing current unemployment through personal re-employment accounts. These are worker-
label: BODY

text: managed accounts of up to $3,000, and they can be used to purchase a variety of re-employment
label: BODY

text: services, including training, counseling, childcare, and transportation.
label: BODY

text: Re-employment accounts will empower individuals by giving them more flexibility,
label: BODY

text: personal choice, and control over their job search.  These accounts also have a re-employment
label: BODY

text: bonus.  Workers who find a new job within 13 weeks will be able to keep the cash balance in their
label: BODY

text: personal re-employment accounts to assist them in transitioning back to work.
label: BODY

text: These personal re-employment accounts will be administered by the states through the local
label: BODY

text: One-Stop Career Centers.  And the President's proposal would provide $3.6 billion in additional
label: BODY

text: resources to the states to fund these personal re-employment accounts over two years so that there
label: BODY

text: will be no duplicative infrastructure that will be needed.
label: BODY

text: As we entered the 21st century, our nation's workforce faced three major challenges:
label: BODY

text: globalization, technological advances, and demographic changes.  So we need long-term strategies,
label: BODY

text: as well, to prepare workers for good-paying jobs in the labor market.
label: BODY

text: This Committee has already recognized the importance of these challenges through its hard
label: BODY

text: work on the Workforce Investment Act of 1998.  Our goal is to continue to develop the One-Stop
label: BODY

text: Career Center delivery system into a cohesive workforce investment system that responds quickly
label: BODY

text: and effectively to the changing needs of our population and our economy.
label: BODY

text: The Administration's proposal for the Workforce Investment Act reauthorization would be
label: BODY

text: based on five key principles.  We want to one, strengthen the governing structure of the workforce
label: BODY

text: investment system by streamlining the membership and mission of state and local workforce
label: BODY

text: investment boards. Two, we want to support a more comprehensive operation with available
label: BODY

text: services through the One-Stop Career Centers. Three, we want to improve adult services by
label: BODY

text: consolidating adult dislocated workers and employment services funding streams into one network.
label: BODY

text: This will increase customer accessibility, as well as state flexibility in responding to local
label: BODY

text: economic conditions. Fourth, we want to better serve at-risk youths by targeting resources to out-
label: BODY

text: of-school youths in both urban and rural areas. And fifth, we want to ensure greater accountability
label: BODY

text: by focusing on the most important outcomes, and eliminating burdensome and duplicative
label: BODY

text: requirements at the state and the local levels.  All federal job-training programs will be measured
label: BODY

text: by the same performance standards.
label: BODY

text: The President's proposals recognize that investments in the workforce are a key part of
label: BODY

text: economic growth.  I believe that these proposals are key to ensuring that our nation's workforce
label: BODY

text: remains the most highly skilled and competitive in the world. I look forward to working with you,
label: BODY

text: Mr. Chairman, and this Committee as we move forward.
label: BODY

text: STATEMENT OF ELAINE L. CHAO, SECRETARY OF LABOR, U.S.

text: Chairman Boehner. Madame Secretary, thank you for your testimony, and thank you for your
label: HH3

text: willingness to come and speak with all of us today.

text: Some are saying that the re-employment bonus that we're talking about in the Back to Work
label: BODY

text: accounts encourages individuals to take the first available job, instead of waiting for the best job.
label: BODY

text: In your testimony that you submitted, you refute this argument by citing evidence from pilot
label: BODY

text: programs showing individuals generally found comparable jobs. Plus someone who chooses to
label: BODY

text: take the job bonus funds obviously has that money and can use it for their own family needs.
label: BODY

text: Is it true that for some individuals labor market attachment can help them advance,
label: BODY

text: suggesting that it's important to become re-employed quickly?
label: BODY

text: Secretary Chao. We believe so.  Now, let me just refer to the pilot programs that you mention.
label: BODY

text: Indeed, our results from the pilot program show that they are helpful in getting people back to
label: BODY

text: work.  We had five pilot programs in four states, and they worked out very well.
label: BODY

text: On the bonus issue, it's not as if a person can get a bonus right away.  Basically, they will
label: BODY

text: receive 60 percent of the bonus upon getting a job, then 40 percent if they stay on the job for six
label: BODY

text: months.
label: BODY

text: We don't believe that workers would just take the first job that they find, and that's what the
label: BODY

text: whole beauty of the personal re-employment account is. It will give them more choice to select the
label: BODY

text: kind of training that is currently not available within the One-Stop Career Centers. So there is a
label: BODY

text: great deal of investment by the individual in the kind of training they want in order to get the job
label: BODY

text: that they want.  So we feel that the re-employment account is actually an incentive to get better
label: BODY

text: training.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: by trade, or have a difficult time.

text: I am deeply honored to have been asked to testify on H.R. 444 and to offer some comments
label: BODY

text: on the reauthorization of the Workforce Investment Act. Mr. Chairman, I would ask that my
label: BODY

text: written testimony, which was provided to you earlier this week, be made part of the record.
label: BODY

text: As you know, every county in America is involved in a local workforce program.  We
label: BODY

text: believe that these programs, as established under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 have been
label: BODY

text: responding to today's workforce crisis effectively and responsively.
label: BODY

text: NACO shares your concern for the ongoing workforce crisis.  Quite simply put, too many
label: BODY

text: people are unemployed, and we must help these people return to work as quickly as possible.  The
label: BODY

text: decision by this Committee to consider legislation that would enhance the existing workforce
label: BODY

text: system is a vote of confidence in the system, and a vote of confidence that we share with you.
label: BODY

text: NACO believes that H.R. 444 is a very important and innovative approach for our
label: BODY

text: unemployment problems, and will enable workforce programs to address the problems of long-
label: BODY

text: term and structural unemployment.  Therefore, we wish to offer our overall support for this bill,
label: BODY

text: and we urge you to adopt it with some modification.
label: BODY

text: We support the efforts to make personal re-employment accounts as part of the workforce
label: BODY

text: development system, limit substantially the amount of funds that may be used at the state and local
label: BODY

text: levels for administrative purposes, institute sufficient flexibility so that individuals may step
label: BODY

text: outside the parameters established through individual training accounts and utilize different types
label: BODY

text: of services and make these funds directly available to recipients.
label: BODY

text: However, we believe that some modifications would be helpful, which include, number
label: BODY

text: one, each individual who receives a personal re-employment account should be required to
label: BODY

text: establish a personal re-employment plan at the local One-Stop system office to which they are
label: BODY

text: referred.
label: BODY

text: Two, as a condition of receiving administrative dollars to operate this program, local
label: BODY

text: workforce investment areas should be required to amend their plans to reflect the kinds of services
label: BODY

text: they will provide to individuals receiving personal re-employment accounts.
label: BODY

text: And three, local workforce investment areas should be permitted to supplement PRA funds
label: BODY

text: with Workforce Investment Act funds to ensure their participants can purchase the types of training
label: BODY

text: and employment assistance they need to achieve the outcomes expressed in their personal re-
label: BODY

text: employment plan.
label: BODY

text: Four, local One-Stop systems should be permitted to charge for any services that the local
label: BODY

text: One-Stop provides, other than the personal re-employment plan, the cost of which should be
label: BODY

text: covered by administrative funds.
label: BODY

text: Individuals who lose their jobs within the first year of employment, through no fault of their
label: BODY

text: own, should be permitted to receive Workforce Investment Act intensive and training services.
label: BODY

text: Funds appropriated for personal re-employment accounts should be in addition to those funds

text: appropriated for other Workforce Investment Act activities.

text: The Back to Work Incentive Act of 2003 should not become a vehicle by which to
label: BODY

text: should be increased in the number and percentage of public sector representatives, especially the
label: BODY

text: mandatory partners, should be reduced substantially, or eliminated.
label: BODY

text: In conclusion, the National Association of Counties believes strongly that workforce
label: BODY

text: development programs represent an important tool for federal, state, and local governments to
label: BODY

text: respond to the continuing employment crisis.
label: BODY

text: While no workforce program can ensure that every American who wishes to work can
label: BODY

text: work, that can only be ensured by a robust economy with substantial job creation capability, we do
label: BODY

text: believe that the current system is well positioned to address the needs of America's unemployed
label: BODY

text: workers and businesses.
label: BODY

text: We believe that the Back to Work Incentive Act, and the Workforce Investment Act, of
label: BODY

text: which it will become a part, if enacted into law, represents important steps towards helping all
label: BODY

text: Americans find work.  We therefore welcome this proposal and endorse it, with the modifications
label: BODY

text: recommended.
label: BODY

text: STATEMENT OF KENNETH MAYFIELD, PRESIDENT, NATIONAL
label: HH2

text: ASSOCIATION OF COUNTIES, WASHINGTON, D.C. – SEE APPENDIX C
label: BODY

text: Mr. McKeon. Thank you very much.
label: HH3

text: Dr. Mishel?
label: BODY

text: STATEMENT OF DR. LAWRENCE MISHEL, PRESIDENT, ECONOMIC
label: HH2

text: POLICY INSTITUTE, WASHINGTON, D.C.
label: HH3

text: Thank you very much, and I appreciate the Committee inviting me to testify on these very
label: BODY

text: important issues.
label: BODY

text: I am going to make three points today.  One is that our labor market is troubled.  There is,
label: BODY

text: essentially, a jobs and income crisis, in my view. Two, the plan that President Bush has proposed
label: BODY

text: will not be very effective at short-term job creation, and will actually destroy jobs in the long run.
label: BODY

text: Three, personal re-employment accounts are far from the answer that the unemployed workers in
label: BODY

text: our country need at this point.
label: BODY

text: Let's turn to the labor market.  As you know, the unemployment rate has risen almost two
label: BODY

text: percentage points over the last two years, and we have lost more than 2 million jobs, 2 million
label: BODY

text: private sector jobs, since unemployment started rising in October of 2000.
label: BODY

text: We also know that household incomes fell in 2001, nearly across the board, and that in
label: BODY

text: 2002, when we have the numbers later this year, I'm sure we will see that household incomes have
label: BODY

text: continued to fall, as I believe they probably are this month, as well.
label: BODY

text: I wanted to point out two things that you may not know about the current labor market
label: BODY

text: situation.  One is a reference to Graph 1 in the testimony, which shows what is the job loss in this
label: BODY

text: recession compared to prior recessions, when you're 28 months into a recession.  And you will note
label: BODY

text: that this recession we have lost 1.8 percent of our private sector jobs after being in a recession 28
label: BODY

text: months.  And this is a greater loss of jobs than even we had in the early 1990s, the early/mid-1980s
label: BODY

text: recession, and the 1970s recession.
label: BODY

text: A second thing I want to point out about the current labor market troubles is that this does
label: BODY

text: not only affect those who are unemployed, it also affects those who are employed, because we are
label: BODY

text: now seeing that wages are falling behind inflation, which we now show on graph two.
label: BODY

text: Graph 2 has two bars for each type of worker:  low wage, middle wage, and high wage
label: BODY

text: workers.  And you will see that in 2001, there is very strong wage growth, faster than inflation,
label: BODY

text: across the board.  But during 2002, we see that wages actually grew less than inflation for nearly
label: BODY

text: every type of worker.
label: BODY

text: This is very problematic, in my view, and calls for attention to how to create jobs and lower
label: BODY

text: unemployment quickly, which brings me to the President's plan, which is labeled a jobs and growth
label: BODY

text: plan, especially for the long term.
label: BODY

text: I am also proud to share with you a statement that was signed this week by 10 Nobel Prize
label: BODY

text: winners, many prominent economists, and 450 economists in total that was released on Monday.
label: BODY

text: And that statement noted that the tax cut plan proposed by President Bush is not the answer.
label: BODY

text: However one views the specifics of the plan, there is wide agreement that its purpose is a
label: BODY

text: permanent change in the tax structure, and not the creation of jobs and growth in the near term.
label: BODY

text: The permanent dividend tax cut, in particular, is not credible as a short-term stimulus.
label: BODY

text: But one need not listen to 10 Nobel Prize winners to know that one can actually look at the
label: BODY

text: actual reports of the current Council of Economic Advisors to know that this is a failed plan.  Their
label: BODY

text: own analysis, which I show in Chart 3, shows that they claim that the plan will create 1.4 million
label: BODY

text: jobs over the next two years, but that after five years, it only has created 700,000 jobs. That means,
label: BODY

text: with simple mathematics, that over the last three years of this five-year period 233,000 jobs a year
label: BODY

text: are lost.  That means, in the long run, we're actually losing jobs.
label: BODY

text: If you look at the projections of a standard forecaster, Mark Zandi of Economy.com, who
label: BODY

text: the Wall Street Journal just recently referred to as one of the smartest, brightest observers of the
label: BODY

text: economic scene, he estimates that by the year 2013, we will have 750,000 fewer jobs than if the
label: BODY

text: Bush plan had never been legislated.  There are many other forecasters who would agree.
label: BODY

text: In the short run, there are some jobs, but it's a lot of money to spend, $674 billion, to create
label: BODY

text: some jobs in the next year or two, when all we need to do is to spend some money on some
label: BODY

text: temporary tax and spending measures to create jobs. I might add that all of the plans offered by the
label: BODY

text: Democrats in both the Senate and the House spend less money overall but spend more money up
label: BODY

text: front and create a lot more jobs up front.
label: BODY

text: Let me turn to the PRAs.  My fear is that the personal re-employment accounts are more
label: BODY

text: about a sense that somehow the unemployed are not really looking hard enough for work and that
label: BODY

text: we need to discipline them by giving them the motivation to get re-employment bonuses.  All of
label: BODY

text: the research that shows that they get re-employed shows that they get re-employed one week
label: BODY

text: earlier.  That's not really a magnificent achievement, in my view. What workers want most are jobs,
label: BODY

text: then they would like income support if they don't have a job, and they would like training with
label: BODY

text: income support if they are unemployed.
label: BODY

text: As I have said, the President's plan does not really create jobs.  We have heard today that
label: BODY

text: there is no offer of extended unemployment insurance benefits, and the training is actually worse
label: BODY

text: under the personal re-employment accounts, than I think under the Workforce Investment Act.
label: BODY

text: If I just may conclude, it's my fear that this proposal is really about curtailing costs, because
label: BODY

text: you're asking people to decide early in their unemployment, are they going to accept this personal
label: BODY

text: re-employment account so they can get a bonus after 13 weeks.  If you accept this, you get $3,000
label: BODY

text: to spend.  But the Secretary earlier said that $3,000 is what, on average, people use.  This is a
label: BODY

text: maximum in this plan. Okay.  Then if you accept this, and you fail to find work, you're not eligible
label: BODY

text: for the intensive services available in the workforce development system.  And then if you're
label: BODY

text: unemployed after 26 weeks, of course, you're not going to get any extended benefits later this year,
label: BODY

text: so you're just out of luck.
label: BODY

text: And so I fear that this is not really going to be that useful to the unemployed.  And thank
label: BODY

text: you very much.
label: BODY

text: STATEMENT OF DR. LAWRENCE MISHEL, PRESIDENT, ECONOMIC
